newsitem.title: CANADA: Researchers develop test for ovarian cancer.
newsitem.headline: Researchers develop test for ovarian cancer.

text.p: A team of researchers said on Thursday it has developed a blood test capable of early detection of ovarian cancer, a leading cause of cancer deaths.

"Diagnosis of ovarian cancer at an early, treatable stage could bring about higher survival rates," said Douglas Gaudette, senior research associate at the University of Guelph and a member of the team that developed the test.
Currently, 70 percent of ovarian cancers are not detected until the disease has reached an advanced stage.
Gaudette and his colleagues found that women with ovarian cancer have a significantly higher level of lysoPC, a normal component of human blood, than that found in healthy women.
The test developed by the team identifies elevated levels of lysoPC in blood tests.
"This finding is a promising start," said Gaudette.

Development of diagnostic tests for ovarian cancer and other types of cancer "could expedite the introduction of intervention strategies at an earlier stage, which may be helpful in preventing malignancy," said Guelph University researcher Bruce Holub, another member of the research team.
Their findings were recently published in the International Journal of Cancer.
Support for the research was provided by the National Cancer Institute of Canada, the Genesis Foundation and the Medical Research Council of Canada.
